A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$.
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
